children.name: Statewide Cost of 28% Cap
companions: Statewide Tax Exempt Muni Bonds Value
children.definition: The estimated cost of a 28 percent cap proposal that state and local governments would have to pay in interest for tax-exempt municipal bonds in the fiscal year if a 28 percent cap were in place over the last 15 years.

children.name: Statewide Cost of Full Repeal
companions: Statewide Tax Exempt Muni Bonds Value
children.definition: The estimated cost of the repeal of the tax-exempt status of municipal bond interest for state and local governments is how much the state and local governments would have had to pay additionally in interest for municipal bonds in the fiscal year if it were fully taxable over the last 15 years.

children.name: Election Registrations
children.source: NACo Analysis of state government website elections data

children.name: Total Registered Voters
children.definition: The number of people in the county who are registered and eligible to vote on the 2016 Presidential Election.

children.name: Democratic
children.definition: The number of registered voters who are affiliated to the Democratic Party.

children.name: Republican
children.definition: The number of registered voters who are affiliated to the Republican Party.

children.name: Other Party
children.definition: The number of registered voters who are affiliated to other parties Party. They include but are not limited to: Libertarian Party, Green Party, United Independent Party, American First Party, Constitution Party, etc.

children.name: Date Updated
children.definition: The date of when these data were reported on their state government elections website.

children.name: General Elections
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Election Assistance Commission, Election Administration and Voting Survey

children.name: Total Registrations
children.definition: Total number of registration forms the county received from all sources during the period from the close of registration for the November 2012 general election until the close of registration for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Registrations by Mail, Fax, or Email
children.definition: The percent of registration forms the county received by mail, fax, or email from the close of registration for the November 2012 general election until the close of registration for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Registrations via the Internet
children.definition: The percent of registration forms the county received via the Internet from the close of registration for the November 2012 general election until the close of registration for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Registrations at Motor Vehicle Offices
children.definition: The percent of registration forms the county received at a motor vehicle offices or other offices that issue drivers licenses from the close of registration for the November 2012 general election until the close of registration for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Registrations Through Other Methods
children.definition: The percent of registration forms the county received via other sources from the close of registration for the November 2012 general election until the close of registration for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Domestic Civilian Absentee Ballots
children.definition: The total number of domestic civilian absentee ballots transmitted to voters for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Physical Polling Places
children.definition: The total number of physical polling places within the county for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: General Election of Precincts
children.definition: The total number of precincts within the county for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Poll Workers
children.definition: The total number of poll workers used by the county for the November 2014 general election.

children.name: General Election Participants
children.definition: The total number of people within the county who participated in the November 2014 general election.

children.name: Government Structure
children.source: NACo Research

children.name: Total Elected Officials
children.definition: Total Number of Elected officials in a county government, including the board officials, elected executives, and any other elected officials.

children.name: Size of Board
children.definition: The size of the elected governing body of the county (number of board members).

children.name: Elected Executive
children.definition: Indicates if the county has an elected executive official.

children.name: Number of Row Officers
children.definition: Other elected county officials, including Sheriffs, District Attorneys, Treasurers and others

children.name: County Administrator
children.definition: Indicates if the county has an administrator, county manager, or similar position.

children.name: City-County Consolidations
children.source: NACo Research

children.name: Consolidation
children.definition: Whether the county is considered a city-county consolidation.

children.name: Government Type
children.definition: The type of government of the county.

children.name: Merging Entities
children.definition: The entities merged with the county during consolidation.

children.name: Year Consolidated
children.definition: Year a city and a county that have been merged into one unified jurisdiction. A consolidated government has the powers and responibilities of both types of entities.

children.name: County Administrators
children.source: NACo analysis
companions: Statewide Number of County Administrator Titles
Enabled by State Statute or County Ordinance

children.name: Appointed County Administrators
children.definition: This indicator explains whether the county has an appointed county administrator, an elected county executive or neither.
children.greyData: Parts of Alaska and Massachusetts colored in grey do not have county governments.

children.name: Statewide Number of County Administrator Titles
children.definition: The total number of titles for all the county administrators in a state.
children.greyData: Parts of Alaska and Massachusetts colored in grey do not have county governments.

children.name: Enabled by State Statute or County Ordinance
children.definition: It indicates whether the county administrators in that state are appointed based on an enabling state statute and/or county ordinance. The “county ordinance” reflects the wider county board’s decision: county ordinance,  resolution and/or position description.
children.greyData: Parts of Alaska and Massachusetts colored in grey do not have county governments.

children.name: Decade of Enabling State Statute
children.definition: Decade of the state law regarding the appointment of county administrators in that state.
children.greyData: States colored in grey do not have enabling state statutes. Parts of Alaska and Massachusetts colored in grey do not have county governments.

children.name: Statewide Total Administrators
children.definition: The total number of appointed administrators in a state.

children.name: County Administrator Profiles
companions: Statewide Number of County Administrator Titles
Enabled by State Statute or County Ordinance
children.definition: The total number of titles for all the county administrators in a state.
children.greyData: Parts of Alaska and Massachusetts colored in grey do not have county governments.

children.name: Population Levels and Trends
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - Population Estimates Program (PEP)
companions: Population Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: Population Level
children.definition: The number of people living in both the incorporated and unincorporated areas of the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Population Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
children.definition: The difference between the population of an area at the beginning and end of a time period, expressed as a percentage of the beginning population.

children.name: Population Change Components
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - Population Estimates Program (PEP)
companions: Population Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: Population Level
children.definition: The number of people living in both the incorporated and unincorporated areas of the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Change in Population (from previous year)
children.definition: The difference in the number of county residents between July 1 of the previous year and July 1 of the source year.

children.name: Births
children.definition: Total number occurring to county residents from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year.

children.name: Deaths
children.definition: Total number occurring to county residents from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year.

children.name: Natural Population Increase
children.definition: Births minus deaths in the county from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year.

children.name: International Migration
children.definition: Any change of the number of county residents due to movement across the borders of the United States (50 states and District of Columbia), from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year.

children.name: Domestic Migration
children.definition: The difference between domestic in-migration to the county and domestic out-migration from the same county from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year. Domestic in- and out-migration consist of moves where both the origin and the destination are within the United States (excluding Puerto Rico).

children.name: Net Migration
children.definition: Domestic migration plus international migration in the county, from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year.

children.name: Birth Rate
children.definition: Births from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year as a proportion of the county's population. Rates are expressed per 1,000 population.

children.name: Death Rate
children.definition: Deaths from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year as a proportion of the county's population. Rates are expressed per 1,000 population.

children.name: Natural Population Increase Rate
children.definition: Natural increase from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year as a proportion of the county's population. Rates are expressed per 1,000 population.

children.name: International Migration Rate
children.definition: International migration from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year as a proportion of the county's population. Rates are expressed per 1,000 population.

children.name: Domestic Migration Rate
children.definition: Domestic migration from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year as a proportion of the county's population. Rates are expressed per 1,000 population.

children.name: Net Migration Rate
children.definition: Net migration from July 1st of the previous year to June 30 of the source year as a proportion of the county's population. Rates are expressed per 1,000 population.

children.name: Population Density
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - Population Estimates Program (PEP)
companions: Population Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: Population Level
children.definition: The number of people living in both the incorporated and unincorporated areas of the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Population Density
children.definition: Number of people per square mile according to the population estimates from the Census Bureau.

children.name: Population Density Growth Rate (from previous year)
children.definition: The difference between the population density of an area at the beginning and end of a time period, expressed as a percentage of the beginning population density.

children.name: Total Land Area
children.definition: Total land area of the county in square miles.

children.name: Population by Age/Gender
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - Population Estimates Program (PEP)

children.name: Total Population Level
children.definition: The number of people living in both the incorporated and unincorporated areas of the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Male Population
children.definition: Total male population in the county as self-identified to the Census Bureau, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent Male
children.definition: Percent male population in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Female Population
children.definition: Total female population in the county as self-identified to the Census Bureau, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent Female
children.definition: Percent female population in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Under 5 years old Population
children.definition: Population under the age of 5 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent Under 5 years old
children.definition: Percentage of people under the age of 5 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: 5-14 years old Population
children.definition: Population between (and including) the ages of 5 and 14 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent 5-14 years old
children.definition: Percentage of people between (and including) the ages of 5 and 14 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: 15-24 years old Population
children.definition: Population of people between (and including) the ages of 15 and 24 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent 15-24 years old
children.definition: Percentage of people between (and including) the ages of 15 and 24 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: 25-64 years old Population
children.definition: Population between (and including) the ages of 25 and 64 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent 25-64 years old
children.definition: Percentage of people between (and including) the ages of 25 and 64 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: 65 years and older Population
children.definition: Population over (and including) the age of 65 years in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Percent 65 years and older
children.definition: Percentage of people over (and including) the age of 65 in the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Population by Ethnicity
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - Population Estimates Program (PEP)
companions: Population Density Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: Total Population
children.definition: The number of people living in both the incorporated and unincorporated areas of the county, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: White Population
children.definition: County residents (not Hispanic) identifying with origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Black or African American Population
children.definition: County residents (not Hispanic) identifying with origins in any of the Black racial groups of Africa, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: American Indian and Alaskan Native Population
children.definition: County residents (not Hispanic) identifying with origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America) and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Asian Population
children.definition: County residents (not Hispanic) identifying with origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent including, for example, Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander Population
children.definition: County residents (not Hispanic) identifying with origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Two or More Races Population
children.definition: County residents (not Hispanic) identifying with two or more races, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Hispanic or Latino Origin Population
children.definition: County residents identifying as a person of Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican, South or Central American, or other Spanish culture or origin regardless of race, as of July 1st of the source year.

children.name: Immigration and Ancestry
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - American Community Survey (ACS) 5 year estimates

children.name: Foreign Born, Not U.S. Citizens
children.definition: Foreign-born residents in a county that are not U.S. citizens.

children.name: Foreign Born, U.S. Citizens
children.definition: Foreign-born residents in a county that are naturalized U.S. citizens.

children.name: Foreign Born Total
children.definition: Foreign-born population includes anyone who is not a U.S. citizen at birth, and excludes population born at sea.

children.name: Percent of Foreign-Born Residents
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population that is foreign-born.

children.name: Percent of Residents with European Ancestry
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population with European first reported ancestry.

children.name: Percent of Residents with Middle Eastern or North African Ancestry
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population with Middle Eastern or North African first reported ancestry.

children.name: Percent of Residents with Sub-Saharan African Ancestry
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population with Sub-Saharan African first reported ancestry.

children.name: Percent of Residents with Australian or New Zealand Ancestry
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population with Australian or New Zealand first reported ancestry.

children.name: Percent of Residents with North American Ancestry
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population with North American first reported ancestry.  U.S. Census Bureau includes in the North American ancestry individuals who identify themselves as American, Cajun, French Canadian, Pennsylvania German, and Canadian.

children.name: Percent of Residents with West Indian or Brazilian Ancestry
children.definition: The percentage of a county's population with West Indian or Brazilian first reported ancestry.

children.name: Refugee Arrivals
children.source: NACo Analysis of Office of Refugee Resettlement, Administration for Children and Families, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
children.definition: The number of refugees arriving in a county in FY 2014.  A refugee is any person who is outside any country of such person's nationality or, in the case of a person having no nationality, is outside any country in which such person last habitually resided, and who is unable or unwilling to return to, and is unable or unwilling to avail himself or herself of the protection of, that country because of persecution or a well-founded fear of persecution on account of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or political opinion.

children.name: Unaccompanied Children
children.source: NACo Analysis of Office of Refugee Resettlement, Administration for Children and Families, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
children.definition: Total Number of Unaccompanied Children Released to Sponsors in FY 2014, by the counties where the sponsors live.  An unaccompanied child is one who enters the country without their parent or legal guardian.  When apprehended by immigration authorities, the child is transferred to the care and custody of the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR).  Federal law requires that ORR feed, shelter, and provide medical care for unaccompanied children until it is able to release them to safe settings with sponsors (usually family members), while they await immigration proceedings. Sponsors are adults who are suitable to provide for the child’s physical and mental well-being and have not engaged in any activity that would indicate a potential risk to the child.

children.name: Veteran Demographics
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - American Community Survey (ACS) 5 year estimates

children.name: Veterans
children.definition: The number of county adult residents (over 18 years old) who are veterans. A 'civilian veteran' is a person 18 years old or over who has served (even for a short time), but is not now serving, on active duty in the U.S. Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, or the Coast Guard, or who served in the U.S. Merchant Marine during World War II. People who served in the National Guard or military reserves are classified as veterans only if they were ever called or ordered to active duty, not counting the 4-6 months for initial training or yearly summer camps. All other civilians 16 years old and over are classified as nonveterans.

children.name: Percent Veterans
children.definition: The proportion of county adult residents (over 18 years old) who are veterans.

children.name: Veterans Median Income
children.definition: Median income for veterans resident in the county, in 2014 inflation adjusted dollars.

children.name: Veterans Less than High School Graduate
children.definition: Veterans, as the proportion of county adult population (25 years and older) that have less than high school diploma as their highest degree of education.

children.name: Veterans High School Graduate
children.definition: Veterans, as the proportion of county adult population (25 years and older) that have high school graduate (including equivalency) as their highest degree of education.

children.name: Veterans Some College or Associate's Degree
children.definition: Veterans, as the proportion of county adult population (25 years and older) that have some college or associate's degree as their highest degree of education.

children.name: Veterans Bachelor's Degree or Higher
children.definition: Veterans, as the proportion of county adult population (25 years and older) that have bachelor's degree or higher as their highest degree of education.

children.name: Veterans Unemployment Rate
children.definition: The unemployment rate for veterans aged 18-64 in the civilian labor force in the county.

children.name: Veterans Poverty Rate
children.definition: The percentage of veterans in a county that are in poverty.

children.name: Local Government Pay
children.source: NACo Analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics - Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages (QCEW)

children.name: Local Government Establishments
children.definition: Number of local government establishments located within a county

children.name: Local Government Employment Level
children.definition: Annual average number of employees working for local government located within a county

children.name: Local Government Weekly Wages
children.definition: Average weekly wages of local government employees located within a county

children.name: Local Government Annual Pay
children.definition: Annual average pay of local government employees located within a county

children.name: Household Income
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau - American Community Survey (ACS) 5 year estimates
companions: Percent of Households with Income Less than $10,000
Percent of Households with Income Between $50,000 - $99,999
Percent of Households with Income of $200,000 or more

children.name: Total Households
children.definition: The number of households in a county. A household consists of all the people who occupy a housing unit. A house, an apartment or other group of rooms, or a single room, is regarded as a housing unit when it is occupied or intended for occupancy as separate living quarters; that is, when the occupants do not live with any other persons in the structure and there is direct access from the outside or through a common hall. A household includes the related family members and all the unrelated people, if any, such as lodgers, foster children, wards, or employees who share the housing unit. A person living alone in a housing unit, or a group of unrelated people sharing a housing unit such as partners or roomers, is also counted as a household. The count of households excludes group quarters.

children.name: Mean Household Income
children.definition: Mean household income is obtained by dividing total household income by the total number of households.

children.name: Median Household Income
children.definition: The amount which divides the income distribution into two equal groups, half having incomes above the median, half having incomes below the median. The medians for households, families, and unrelated individuals are based on all households, families, and unrelated individuals, respectively. The medians for people are based on people 15 years old and over with income.

children.name: Number of Households with Income Less than $10,000
children.definition: The number of households located in the county with a household income of less than $10,000. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Percent of Households with Income Less than $10,000
children.definition: The percentage of households located in the county with a household income of less than $10,000. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Number of Households with Income Between $10,000 - $24,999
children.definition: The number of households located in the county with a household income of between $10,000 and $24,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Percent of Households with Income Between $10,000 - $24,999
children.definition: The percentage of households located in the county with a household income of between $10,000 and $24,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Number of Households with Income Between $25,000 - $49,999
children.definition: The number of households located in the county with a household income of between $25,000 and $49,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Percent of Households with Income Between $25,000 - $49,999
children.definition: The percentage of households located in the county with a household income of between $25,000 and $49,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Number of Households with Income Between $50,000 - $99,999
children.definition: The number of households located in the county with a household income of between $50,000 and $99,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Percent of Households with Income Between $50,000 - $99,999
children.definition: The percentage of households located in the county with a household income of between $50,000 and $99,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Number of Households with Income Between $100,000 - $199,999
children.definition: The number of households located in the county with a household income of between $100,000 and $199,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Percent of Households with Income Between $100,000 - $199,999
children.definition: The percentage of households located in the county with a household income of between $100,000 and $199,999. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Number of Households with Income of $200,000 or more
children.definition: The number of households located in the county with a household income of $200,000 or more. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Percent of Households with Income of $200,000 or more
children.definition: The percentage of households located in the county with a household income of $200,000 or more. This includes the income of the householder and all other individuals 15 years old and over in the household, whether they are related to the householder or not.

children.name: Labor Force
children.source: NACo Analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics - Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS)

children.name: Civilian Labor Force Population
children.definition: All persons in the civilian noninstitutional population classified as either employed or unemployed.

children.name: Number Employed
children.definition: These are all persons who, during the reference week (the week including the 12th day of the month), (a) did any work as paid employees, worked in their own business or profession or on their own farm, or worked 15 hours or more as unpaid workers in an enterprise operated by a member of their family, or (b) were not working but who had jobs from which they were temporarily absent because of vacation, illness, bad weather, childcare problems, maternity or paternity leave, labor-management dispute job training, or other family or personal reasons, whether or not they were paid for the time off or were seeking other jobs. Each employed person is counted only once, even if he or she holds more than one job.

children.name: Number Unemployed
children.definition: Included are all persons who had no employment during the reference week, were available for work, except for temporary illness, and had made specific efforts to find employment some time during the 4 week-period ending with the reference week. Persons who were waiting to be recalled to a job from which they had been laid off need not have been looking for work to be classified as unemployed.

children.name: Unemployment Rate
children.definition: Number of persons unemployed as a percent of the labor force.

children.name: County Economies
children.source: NACo Analysis of Moody's Analytics data

children.name: County Economic Profile
children.definition: A comprehensive printable report, individualized for each county economy.

children.name: Adjusted Average County Wage
companions: Adjusted Average County Wage Growth Rate
children.definition: Cost-of-living adjusted pay for the county economy reflecting price differences between county economies.

children.name: Adjusted Average County Wage Growth Rate
children.source: NACo analysis of Census Bureau ACS 5-year estimates, U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis and U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics
companions: Adjusted Average County Wage Growth Rate
children.definition: Year-over-year growth rate in the average pay in the county economy, adjusted to reflect cost-of-living differences between county economies and price changes over time.  This research adjusts for the cost-of-living with a price index based on the median gross rent from the American Community Survey (ACS) and for inflation using U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index.

children.name: Unemployment Rate Change
children.definition: The difference between 2014 and 2015 unemployment rates in a county economy.  Shown in percentage points.  The unemployment rate is the proportion of the civilian labor force that is unemployed in a county economy.  Persons are classified as unemployed if they do not have a job, have actively looked for work in the prior four weeks and are currently available for work.

children.name: Jobs Growth Rate
children.definition: Year-over-year jobs growth rate.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.

children.name: GDP Growth Rate
children.definition: Year-over-year inflation-adjusted economic output (real GDP) growth rate.  Real GDP is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.

children.name: Home Price Growth Rate
children.definition: Year-over-year Median Home Sales Prices growth rate.  Median Home Sales Prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.

children.name: Jobs Growth Rate, Long-term
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of jobs (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from 1990 to the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy. It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.

children.name: GDP Growth Rate, Long-term
children.definition: The inflation-adjusted annualized growth rate of GDP (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from 1990 to the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.

children.name: Home Price Growth Rate, Long-term
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of median home sales prices (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from 1990 to the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009.  Median home sales prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.

children.name: Unemployment Rate Change, Recession
children.definition: The difference in the Unemployment Rate from the lowest annual rate between 2002 and 2009 to the highest annual rate recorded after that up to 2015.  Shown in percentage points.  The unemployment rate is the proportion of the civilian labor force that is unemployed in a county economy.  Persons are classified as unemployed if they do not have a job, have actively looked for work in the prior four weeks and are currently available for work.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.

children.name: Jobs Growth Rate, Recession
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of jobs (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009 to the lowest number of jobs recorded after that until 2015.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.

children.name: GDP Growth Rate, Recession
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of GDP (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009 to the lowest annual GDP recorded after that until 2015.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.

children.name: Home Price Growth Rate, Recession
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of median home sales prices (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009 to the lowest home price level recorded after that until 2015.  Median home sales prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.

children.name: Unemployment Rate Change, Recovery
children.definition: The difference in the annual unemployment rate from the highest annual rate since 2002 to the 2015 value.  The unemployment rate is the proportion of the civilian labor force that is unemployed in a county economy.  Persons are classified as unemployed if they do not have a job, have actively looked for work in the prior four weeks and are currently available for work.  A county economy that had no increases in the unemployment rate between 2002 and 2009 will show the change from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.

children.name: Jobs Growth Rate, Recovery
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of jobs (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the trough to the 2015 value.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.  A county economy that has not had a recession will show the annualized growth rate from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.

children.name: GDP Growth Rate, Recovery
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of GDP (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the trough to the 2015 value.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.  A county economy that has not had a recession will show the annualized growth rate from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.

children.name: Home Price Growth Rate, Recovery
children.definition: The annualized growth rate of median home sales prices (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the trough to the 2015 value.  Median Home Sales Prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.  A county economy that has not had a recession will show the annualized growth rate from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.

children.name: Unemployment Rate Recovered
children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its unemployment rate pre-recession low (the lowest annual rate between 2002 and 2009) by 2015.

children.name: Jobs Recovered
children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its employment pre-recession peak (the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009) by 2015. Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.

children.name: Home Prices Recovered
children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its home prices pre-recession peak (the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009) by 2015.  Median home sales prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.

children.name: GDP Recovered
children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its real GDP pre-recession peak (the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009) by 2015.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.

children.name: Recovered on # Indicators
children.definition: The total number of indicators on which this county economy has recovered by 2015 or has experienced no recession since 2002.  Indicators analyzed: jobs, unemployment rates, economic output (GDP) and median home prices.

children.name: Average Real Wage Growth vs Productivity Growth
children.source: NACo Analysis of Moody’s Analytics 2015 Data; U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Data
children.definition:
Average Real Wages: Average annual pay in a county economy, adjusted for inflation. To compare to productivity, this analysis estimates average real wages in 2009 dollars by adjusting average county wages with the BLS Producer Price Index.
Productivity: The inflation-adjusted economic output (real GDP in 2009 dollars) produced by an average job located in the county.
Average County Wage: Average annual pay of a job with the industries located in a county. These wages reflect salaries, bonuses, the cash value of meals and lodging when supplied, tips and other gratuities, and, in some states, employer contributions to certain deferred compensation plans such as 401(k) plans, and stock options. BLS does not include the following categories in the jobs reporting these wages: self-employed workers, most agricultural workers on small farms, all members of the Armed Forces, elected officials in most states, most employees of railroads, some domestic workers, most student workers at schools and employees of certain small nonprofit organizations.

children.name: International Exports
children.source: Brookings Institution Export Monitor 2015. For more on the methodology, see here

children.name: Total Exports
children.definition: sales of goods and services by U.S. resident firms located in the county to foreign entities (people or companies).  These estimates reflect the value of exports by location of production and not by origin-of-movement, as is the norm with all the other available export databases.  The foreign entities include foreign firms located abroad (but no affiliates of foreign companies located in the United States), subsidiaries of American firms located abroad, foreign tourists and students in the United States and foreign passengers on U.S. air carriers.

children.name: Export Share of GDP
children.definition: or export intensity shows the importance of exports to the economy.

children.name: Total Export-Supported Jobs
children.definition: includes direct export-production jobs as well as jobs supported by exports in the suppliers to the exporting industry, and in the case of goods exports, in the transportation and wholesale trade industries.  Some portion of these jobs lies outside the county producing the export and in other parts of the United States.

children.name: Export Growth Rate
children.definition: is the real growth rate of exports value between 2013 and 2014, inflation-adjusted by industry.

children.name: U.S. Ex-Im Bank Financing
children.source: NACo Analysis of Export Import Bank of the United States data covering 2007-2014.  Data is current as of October 6th
companions: Share of Small Business Supported Exporters

children.name: U.S. Ex-Im Bank County Profiles
children.definition: A report on the Ex-Im support given to businesses in a particular county over the course of 2007-2014.

children.name: Supported Exporters
children.definition: The number of unique exporting businesses located in a county and receiving export financing from the Export Import Bank of the United States between 2007 and 2014. To qualify for U.S. Ex-Im Bank support, a business must export goods or services produced with more than 50% U.S. parts and labor.

children.name: Share of Small Business Supported Exporters
children.definition: TThe share of U.S. Ex-Im Bank supported exporters in a county that are small businesses. According to the U.S. Small Business Administration's definition, small businesses have less than 500 employees for most manufacturing and mining industries and $7.5 million in average annual receipts for many nonmanufacturing industries. There are a number of exceptions- for more see here.

children.name: U.S. Ex-Im Bank Export Financing
children.definition: The total dollar value of shipments from 2007-2014 of U.S. Ex-Im Bank supported exporters located in a county.

children.name: Supported Exports
children.definition: The dollar value of exports between 2007 and 2014 of U.S. Ex-Im Bank supported exporters located in a county.

children.name: Economic Conditions
children.source: NACo Analysis of Moody's Analytics data

children.name: County Tracker
children.definition: Number of persons unemployed as a percent of the labor force.

children.name: County Job Skills
children.source: NACo Analysis of Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) data

children.name: Level
children.definition: The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) classification of the county's state of supply and demand for skilled labor. The skills supply is the share of the working age county population having post-secondary education, based on the 2012 5-year estimate American Community Survey (ACS). The skills demand is a combined index of the share of county residents having medium and high skilled occupations and income from employment. For more on the methodology, click here

children.name: Public Elementary & Secondary Schools
children.source: NACo Analysis of National Center for Economic Statistics (NCES) - Common Core Data (CCD), Elementary and Secondary Information System (ELSi)

children.name: Number of Districts
children.definition: The number of school districts located in the county.

children.name: Number Operational Schools
children.definition: The number of operational schools located in the county.

children.name: Number of Locally-Operated Institutions
children.definition: The number of Locally Operated institutions located in the county.

children.name: Number of Federally-operated Institutions
children.definition: The number of Federally Operated institutions located in the county.

children.name: Number of State-operated Institutions
children.definition: The number of State Operated institutions located in the county.

children.name: Number of Charter School Agencies
children.definition: The number of Charter School agencies located in the county.

children.name: Number of Other School Agencies
children.definition: The number of Supervisory Union Administrative centers, Regional education services agencies, and other education agencies located in the county.

children.name: Total Students
children.definition: The total number of students in all the school districts located in the county.

children.name: FTE Teachers
children.definition: The total number of Full-Time Equivalent teachers working in all the school districts located in the county.

children.name: Pupil/Teacher Ratio
children.definition: The ratio of total students to full-time equivalent teachers in the county.

children.name: Colleges & Universities
children.source: NACo Analysis of National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) - Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS)

children.name: Number of Institutions
children.definition: The number of institutions that have been accredited at the college level by an agency or association recognized by the Secretary, U.S. Department of Education.

children.name: Number of Public Institutions
children.definition: The number of higher education institutions that are operated by publicly elected or appointed officials.

children.name: Number of less than 4 year Institutions
children.definition: The number of institutions with programs that are less than 4 years

children.name: Number of 4 year or Higher Institutions
children.definition: The number of institutions with programs that are 4 years or higher

children.name: Total Enrollment
children.definition: The number of students enrolled in all institutions in the county. Includes students enrolled in courses creditable toward a degree or other formal award; students enrolled in courses that are part of a vocational or occupational program, including those enrolled in off-campus or extension center; and high school students taking regular college courses for credit.

children.name: Male Enrollment
children.definition: The number of male students enrolled in all institutions in the county. Includes students enrolled in courses creditable toward a degree or other formal award; students enrolled in courses that are part of a vocational or occupational program, including those enrolled in off-campus or extension center; and high school students taking regular college courses for credit.

children.name: Female Enrollment
children.definition: The number of female students enrolled in all institutions in the county. Includes students enrolled in courses creditable toward a degree or other formal award; students enrolled in courses that are part of a vocational or occupational program, including those enrolled in off-campus or extension center; and high school students taking regular college courses for credit.

children.name: Average In-State Tuition
children.definition: The tuition charged by institutions to those students who meet the state's or institution's residency requirements.

children.name: Average Out-of-State Tuition
children.definition: The tuition charged by institutions to those students who do not meet the institution's or state's residency requirements.

children.name: Educational Attainment
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Census Bureau

children.name: Less than 9th Grade
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of less than 9th grade.

children.name: 9th to 12th Grade
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of between 9th and 12th grade with no diploma.

children.name: High School Graduate
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of a high school graduate, including equivalency.

children.name: Some College
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of some college, with no degree.

children.name: Associate's Degree
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of an associate's degree.

children.name: Bachelor's Degree
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of a bachelor's degree.

children.name: Graduate or Professional Degree
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of a graduate or professional degree.

children.name: Above K-12
children.definition: The percentage of the county's over-25 population with a highest degree of education of between kindergarten and 12th grade.

children.name: Coal Use & Production
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Energy Information Adminstration Data

children.name: Coal-fueled Power Plants
children.definition: The number of power plants in a county for which coal is the energy source for at least one generator.

children.name: Number of Coal Mines
children.definition: Total number of coal mines in a county.  The total includes both underground and surface mines.

children.name: Coal Production
children.definition: Total number of short tons of coal produced in a county.

children.name: Endangered Species
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service data, as of May 2015
companions: Number of Endangered and Threatened Species Listings

children.name: Endangered Species Profiles
children.definition: An endangered species is a species in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A threatened species is a species likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A species may be treated as endangered or threatened if it resembles in appearance a species which has been listed under section 4 and enforcement personnel would have difficulty distinguishing between the listed and the unlisted species; if the effect of this difficulty is an additional threat to the listed species; and if such treatment of the unlisted species would improve protection for the listed species. A similarity of appearance listing must be promulgated or formalized by rule.  Such species are not biologically endangered or threatened and are not subject to Section 7 consultation.  In some counties threatened species includes experimental non-essential populations.  Experimental, nonessential populations of endangered species (e.g., red wolf) are treated as threatened species on public land, for consultation purposes, and as species proposed for listing on private land.

children.name: Number of Endangered and Threatened Species Listings
children.definition: An endangered species is a species in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A threatened species is a species likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A species may be treated as endangered or threatened if it resembles in appearance a species which has been listed under section 4 and enforcement personnel would have difficulty distinguishing between the listed and the unlisted species; if the effect of this difficulty is an additional threat to the listed species; and if such treatment of the unlisted species would improve protection for the listed species. A similarity of appearance listing must be promulgated or formalized by rule.  Such species are not biologically endangered or threatened and are not subject to Section 7 consultation.  In some counties threatened species includes experimental non-essential populations.  Experimental, nonessential populations of endangered species (e.g., red wolf) are treated as threatened species on public land, for consultation purposes, and as species proposed for listing on private land.

children.name: Number of Endangered Species Listings
children.definition: An endangered species is a species in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.

children.name: Number of Threatened Species Listings
children.definition: A threatened species is a species likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  In some counties threatened species includes experimental non-essential populations.  Experimental, nonessential populations of endangered species (e.g., red wolf) are treated as threatened species on public land, for consultation purposes, and as species proposed for listing on private land.

children.name: Number of New Listings of Endangered and Threatened Species
children.definition: The number of species added to endangered or threatened status from 2004-May 2015.

children.name: Number of Delistings of Endangered and Threatened Species
children.definition: The number of species removed from endangered or threatened status.

children.name: Air Quality
children.source: NACo Analysis of Environmental Protection Agency data

children.name: Particulate Matter 2.5 Concentration
children.definition: Category indicating whether the county's 2013-2015 3-year concentration level of ground-level particulate matter (<2.5μm) as measured by county monitors.  Categories in micrograms per cubic meter: under 5, 5-6.9, 7-8.9, 9 and Above.

children.name: 2013-2015 Ozone Level
children.definition: Category indicating whether the county's 2013-2015 3-year concentration level of ground-level ozone as measured by county monitors is under 60 parts per billion, 60-64 parts per billion, 65-69 parts per billion or 70 and above parts per billion.

children.name: Projected 2025 Ozone Level
children.definition: Category indicating whether the model projections for 2025 of the county's projected 3-year concentration levels of ground-level ozone as measured by county monitors is under 60 parts per billion, 60-64 parts per billion, 65-69 parts per billion or 70 and above parts per billion.

children.name: 2013-2015 Ozone Count
children.definition: 2013-2015 3-year concentration levels of ground-level ozone as measured by county monitors

children.name: Projected 2025 Ozone Count
children.definition: Model projections for 2025 of 3-year levels of ground-level ozone concentration as measured by county monitors.

children.name: Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA)
children.source: U.S. Department of Labor, Employment and Training Administration, State Statutory Formula Funding data, Program Year, 2015
companions: Statewide Number in Substantial Unemployment Areas

children.name: Statewide Adult WIOA Funding
children.definition: Amount of WIOA funding allocated by the U.S. Department of Labor to the state for adult employment and training activities for Program Year (July 1 of program year to June 30 of the following year).

children.name: Statewide Adult WIOA Growth Rate
children.definition: Percent change in the amount of WIOA Adult funding allotted to the state in Program Year 2014 and Program Year 2015.

children.name: Statewide Number in Substantial Unemployment Areas
children.definition: Average number of unemployed individuals in the state that are in areas of substantial unemployment between July 1, 2013 and June 30, 2014.  An area of substantial unemployment is a contiguous area of counties, cities, towns, townships, other minor civil divisions and/or census tracts that has a combined population of at least 10,000 and an average unemployment rate of at least 6.5 percent. One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.

children.name: Statewide Number of Excess Unemployed
children.definition: Average number of unemployed in excess of 4.5 percent between July 1, 2013 and June 30, 2014.  The number of excess unemployed is determined by the higher of unemployment in excess of 6.5 percent in areas of substantial unemployment or excess unemployment in all areas.  One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.

children.name: Statewide Number of Disadvantaged Adults
children.definition: Number of adults between 22 and 72 years (or their family members) who are economically disadvantaged based on a 5 year estimate between 2006 and 2010.  The number of economically disadvantaged adults (or their family members) is determined by the Census poverty level or at 70 percent of the Lower Living Standard Income Level.  One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.

children.name: Statewide Youth WIOA Funding
companions: Statewide Number in Substantial Unemployment Areas
children.definition: Amount of WIOA funding allocated by the U.S. Department of Labor to the state for youth activities for Program Year (July 1 of program year to June 30 of the following year).

children.name: Statewide Youth WIOA Growth Rate
children.definition: Percent change in the amount of WIOA Adult funding allotted to the state in Program Year 2014 and Program Year 2015.

children.name: Statewide Number of Disadvantaged Youth
children.definition: Number of individuals between 16 and 21 years (or their family members) who are economically disadvantaged based on a 5 year estimate between 2006 and 2010.  The number of economically disadvantaged youth (or their family members) is determined by the Census poverty level or at 70 percent of the Lower Living Standard Income Level.  One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.

children.name: Local WDB Service Area
children.source: NACo analysis of U.S. Department of Labor data, 2015
children.definition:
Counties are classified into one of the following five categories based on the type of local workforce development board (local WDB) serving the county: State Level, Single County, Multiple Counties, County and City or City, as of October 2015.
  • State Level means a county is in the service area of a state run workforce board that fulfills the responsibilities of a local WDB under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act.
  • Single County indicates the local WDB serves only the area of one county.
  • Multiple Counties indicates the local WDB serves the area of two or more counties.
  • County and City means a county and one or more cities, including independent cities, are in the service area of a local WDB.
  • A City local WDB serves only some cities within the county so that the entire county is served by multiple local WDBs.

children.name: Statewide Dislocated Worker Funding
companions: Statewide Number in Substantial Unemployment Areas
children.definition: Amount of WIOA funding allocated by the U.S. Department of Labor to the state for dislocated workers for Program Year (July 1 of program year to June 30 of the following year).

children.name: Veteran Expenditures
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs Data

children.name: Total Veterans Expenditures
children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures within the county jurisdiction, for items such as: compensation and pension; education and vocational rehabilitation and employment; insurance and indemnities; construction and related costs; general operating expenses and related costs; loan guaranty; and medical expenditures.

children.name: Compensation and Pension
children.definition: Federal compensation and pension benefits to veterans resident in the county.  It includes: veterans' compensation for service-connected disabilities; dependency and indemnity compensation for service-connected deaths; veterans' pension for nonservice-connected disabilities; and burial and other benefits to veterans and their survivors.

children.name: Education and Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment
children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures on education and vocational rehabilitation and employment.  These expenditures to veterans include automobile and adaptive equipment, specially adapted housing, survivors’ and dependents’ educational assistance (chapter 35), vocational rehabilitation for disabled veterans (chapter 31), post-Vietnam era veterans’ educational assistance (chapter 32), Montgomery G.I.  Bill for selected reserves (chapter 1606), reserve educational assistance program (chapter 1607), Montgomery G.I.  Bill (Chapter 30), and post-9/11 veterans educational assistance (chapter 33).

children.name: Insurance and Indemnities
children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures on insurance and indemnities.  These expenditures to veterans consist of VA expenditures for death claims, matured endowments, dividends, cash surrender payments, total disability income provision payments, and total and permanent disability benefits payments.

children.name: Medical Care
children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures on medical care, consisting of operating expenses incurred through the provision of healthcare services to veterans. These expenditures include dollars for medical services, medical administration, facility maintenance, educational support, research support, and other overhead items.  Medical care expenditures do not include dollars for construction or other non-medical support.  Medical care expenditures are based on where patients live instead of where care is delivered.

children.name: VA Healthcare Facility Patients
children.definition: Patients residing in the county who received treatment at a VA health care facility.

children.name: Medical Benefits
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, Local Area Personal Income and Employment Data

children.name: Medical Benefits
children.definition: Federal government payments for medical care, including Medicare benefits, public assistance medical care benefits and military medical insurance benefits received by the residents of a county.

children.name: Medicare Benefits
children.definition: Federal government payments made directly or through intermediaries to vendors for the care provided to individuals under the Medicare program.

children.name: Public Assistance Medical Care Benefits
children.definition: Federal government medical benefits to low-income individuals, comprised of Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) benefits.

children.name: Military Medical Insurance Benefits
children.definition: Vendor payments made under the TRICARE Management Program, formerly called the Civilian Health and Medical Plan of the Uniformed Services, for the medical care of dependents of active duty military personnel and of retired military personnel and their dependents at nonmilitary medical facilities.

children.name: Medicaid Contribution Mandate
children.source: NACo Research
children.definition: Identifies if counties within a state contribute to Medicaid, and if they are mandated by the state to do so or not.

children.name: Airports Funding
children.source: Federal Aviation Administration and Office of Aviation Analysis, U.S. Department of Transportation data

children.name: Airport Investment Program Total
children.definition: The total amount received by county airports in federal fiscal year 2014 from the Airport Investment Program (AIP) in a county.  Some amounts may be preliminary estimates, subject to change prior to award.  Data current as of September 30, 2015.

children.name: Airport Investment Program Entitlement
children.definition: The entitlement amount received by county airports from the Airport Investment Program (AIP) in a county for federal fiscal year 2014.  Some amounts may be preliminary estimates, subject to change prior to award.  Data current as of September 30, 2015.

children.name: Airport Investment Program Discretionary
children.definition: The discretionary amount received by county airports from the Airport Investment Program (AIP) in a county for federal fiscal year 2014.  Some amounts may be preliminary estimates, subject to change prior to award.  Data current as of September 30, 2015.

children.name: Essential Air Service Annual Subsidy
children.definition: The amount received by subsidized air service carriers serving communities within a county under the Essential Air Service (EAS) program, as of April 2016.

children.name: American Dream Downpayment Initiative (ADDI)
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
companions: ADDI Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
HUD Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: ADDI Amount
children.definition: Funding received for the American Dream Downpayment Initiative program

children.name: ADDI Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
children.definition: Percent change in funding for the American Dream Downpayment Initiative program from the previous year

children.name: Byrne (JAG) Program Awards
children.source: NACo analysis of U.S. Department of Justice, Office of Justice Programs, Bureau of Justice Assistance data

children.name: JAG Amount
children.definition: Funding received by the county from the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant (JAG) Program.  This amount includes funding allocated directly to and received by the county from the federal government.  It also includes the total amount of a joint allocation from the federal government that is shared by the county and one or more cities within the county. The county's share of a joint allocation is set through an agreement between the jurisdictions that share the allocation.  The amount does not include pass-through funds that may have been received by the county from an award made to the state.

children.name: Receives Individual Award
children.definition: Indicates whether the county receives an individual award directly from the federal government that is not shared with another jurisdiction.

children.name: Receives Share of Award
children.definition: Indicates whether the county receives a share of funding through a joint allocation from the federal government.  The county's share of a joint allocation is set through an agreement between the jurisdictions that share the allocation.

children.name: Community Development Block Grants (CDBG)
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development data
companions: CDBG Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
HUD Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: CDBG Profiles
children.definition: Formula Community Development Block Grants (CDBG) money going to entitlement counties directly from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.  Other counties can receive funding from the Small Cities CDBG program through their states. The Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program funds counties and others communities to ensure affordable housing, to provide services to the most vulnerable in our communities and to create jobs through the expansion and retention of businesses.

children.name: CDBG Amount
children.definition: Formula Community Development Block Grants (CDBG) money going to entitlement counties directly from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.  Other counties can receive funding from the Small Cities CDBG program through their states. The Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program funds counties and others communities to ensure affordable housing, to provide services to the most vulnerable in our communities and to create jobs through the expansion and retention of businesses.

children.name: CDBG Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
children.definition: Percent change in formula CDBG funding for entitlement counties from the previous year.

children.name: Emergency Shelter Grants (ESG)
children.source: NACo Analysis of U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development data
companions: ESG Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
HUD Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: ESG Amount
children.definition: Funding received by a county from the Emergency Shelter Grants program. Recipients use Emergency Shelter Grants Program funds to rehabilitate and operate emergency shelters and transitional shelters, provide essential social services and prevent homelessness.

children.name: ESG Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
children.definition: Percent change in funding for the Emergency Shelter Grants program from the previous year.

HUD Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)

children.name: HOME Amount

The HOME Investment Partnerships Program (HOME) provides formula grants to States and localities to fund a wide range of activities including building, buying, and/or rehabilitating affordable housing for rent or homeownership or providing direct rental assistance to low-income people.

children.name: HOME Annual Growth Rate (from previous year)
children.definition: Percent change in funding for the HOME Investment Partnership Program program from the previous year.

children.name: PILT & SRS
